Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Coherence as a Basis for Understanding Teachers' Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This CAREER project investigates Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching (MKT) from the perspective of coherent understanding. The PI will explore not only how much knowledge teachers possess but also how they organize that knowledge, and how that organization shapes their practice. This proposed project builds on scholarly work about the development of expertise from the learning sciences and the work about the mathematics knowledge teachers need and how that knowledge develops from mathematics education. The PI's research approach was innovative and will use a mixture of qualitative and quantitative methods to investigate how much knowledge teachers possess and how they organize that knowledge for teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CAREER: Coherence as a Basis for Understanding Teachers’ Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching was funded in 2010 and ended in 2017. As a grant for providing a foundation for successful careers in academia, this project was a clear success. During the project, the PI was promoted from Assistant Professor to Associate Professor, became the chair of her department, and served as an Interim Co-Director for the Kaput Center for Research & Innovation in STEM Education. Soon, she will be transitioning to be the permanent director of the Kaput Center, which allows her to work with other researchers to build their own research agendas.

 

This CAREER grant focused on three key research questions:

  • How do teachers’ conceptual organizations of MKT for proportional reasoning relate to their performance on assessments of content knowledge?
  • How do teachers’ with varying levels of content knowledge compare to experts in terms of their conceptual organization of the domain?
  • How is the coherence of teachers’ conceptual organizations related to their classroom practices for teaching proportional reasoning?

To answer these questions, we asked 32 practicing middle school teachers to complete an assessment about Proportions, to complete a think-aloud protocol focused on solving proportional problems and examining the thinking of others, and to participate in a 90 minute interview in which we had them explore dynamic proportional relationships using software and analyze the thinking of others.

 

We are using a variety of analysis methods – both qualitative and quantitative – to answer these questions. We used the knowledge in pieces framework as our conceptual lens and are applying Epistemic Network Analysis as one of our key analytical lenses.

 

To date, we have produced two published journal articles, 10 peer-reviewed published proceedings papers, and 24 presentations (across six organizations). We have 2 accepted presentations, one presentation proposal under review, and three journal manuscripts in preparation. We have also re-programmed the Fraction Bars software, which is now freely available at http://www.kaputcenter.umassd.edu/products/software/fractionbars/. This was done in support of the course Proportional Reasoning for Teachers, which was developed as part of this grant and taught two times to practicing middle grades teachers in our region. In all, seven Ph.D. students have been involved in this research project and one researcher from another institution is also part of the research team.

 

We are still analyzing data and will continue to do so for several more years. A couple of findings to date that are particularly interesting include that we have identified a set of knowledge resources invoked when teachers engage in proportional reasoning. We have found that six of these resources have a positive correlation to performance on the assessment. Of those, five are concerned with proportional structures. These included understanding that the relationship between quantities in a proportion is multiplicative; recognizing that as one quantity varies, the other quantity must vary in the same way to maintain the relationship; being about to identify that there is new quantity formed by the relationship between the two quantities in the proportion (e.g., flavor or speed); recognizing that there is an invariant constant relationship between the quantities; and recognizing when a situation involves proportional reasoning. The sixth code that showed a positive correlation was the ability to talk about or build from the mathematical thinking of others.

Another interesting finding is that teachers reason differently in paper and pencil situations than in computer-based (dynamic) situations. This raises a number of questions about how we might be able to capitalize on technology to help teachers (and, presumably students) build more robust understandings of proportions.

 

We also found that middle school teachers in this study were good at identifying situations that are proportional. However, some struggle to identify situations that are not proportional. For example, they tend to see linear relationships as being proportional even when they are not.

 

In one small case study, we also saw that one teacher focused students on his preferred method for solving a proportion when he taught his seventh graders. This is interesting because the teacher had a wide range of knowledge resources available (as demonstrated in his interviews), but he also had concerns about his students’ abilities and strengths combined with his personal preference for solving problems. Those factors drove him to move students away from their preferred solution method to his preferred solution method. This is important because little is known about how teachers make decisions in the moment and the effects that teacher knowledge has on those decisions. We are starting to uncover some of the facets of teacher decision making that shape students’ learning experiences. In the long run, this will inform the design of teacher professional development efforts.
